summary: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. is eager to stand out. Just not too much. In a Twitter message sent Thursday afternoon, Mr. Huntsman wrote:

headline: JPMorgan Is Investing In Twitter Indirectly
summary: Chris Sacca is known in Silicon Valley for his Western-style button-down shirts and his early investments in start-up companies like Twitter. But for big institutional investors, Mr. Sacca, 35, is becoming known as an important gatekeeper in meeting the demand for the private shares of fast-growing Internet companies.

headline: Room for Both IPad and Kindle
summary: O.K., here goes: when it comes to the Amazon Kindle, I'll admit it, I was wrong. When the AppleiPad was announced in January, I wrote a blog post that predicted ''Three Reasons Why the iPad Will Kill Amazon's Kindle.'' I noted that Amazon isn't innovating fast enough and that as a single-purpose reading device, the Kindle was just too expensive.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths PAPE, MICHAEL V.
summary: PAPE--Michael V. passed away on January 5, 2011 at his residence in Scarsdale. He was 95 years old. Mr. Pape was born August 12, 1915 in Greenpoint Brooklyn to Joseph and Rose Pontone Pape. Mr. Pape married his late wife Maria T. pape on September 7, 1940 at Sacred Heart Church in Brooklyn. Mr. Pape was the president of Ace Gear Industries Inc. and member of the Scarsdale American Legion. He was a veteran of the United States Army. Mr. Pape is survived by two sons Dr. Lawrence G. Pape and Dr. J. Gerard Pape. Also surviving are three grandchildren Samuel, Louis and Andre Pape. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10am Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting hours Saturday, Sunday and Monday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Reposing at Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Homes, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY 10583.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths PAPE, MICHAEL V
summary: PAPE--Michael V. passed away on January 5, 2011 at his residence in Scarsdale. He was 95 years old. Mr. Pape was born August 12, 1915 in Greenpoint Brooklyn to Joseph and Rose Pontone Pape. Mr. Pape married his late wife Maria T. pape on September 7, 1940 at Sacred Heart Church in Brooklyn. Mr. Pape was the president of Ace Gear Industries Inc. and member of the Scarsdale American Legion. He was a veteran of the United States Army. Mr. Pape is survived by two sons Dr. Lawrence G. Pape and Dr. J. Gerard Pape. Also surviving are three grandchildren Samuel, Louis and Andre Pape. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10am Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting hours Saturday, Sunday and Monday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Reposing at Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Homes, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY 10583.

headline: DealBook Online
summary: GRASSLEY QUESTIONS S.E.C. Senator Charles E. Grassley, left, Republican of Iowa, has peppered the S.E.C. with letters asking it to explain its response to 19 reports of suspicious trading at SAC Capital Advisors. Now, Mr. Grassley has escalated his confrontation with the S.E.C., saying it received 65 reports. ''This substantially expands the number of referrals in the S.E.C.'s possession to 65 which, thus far, you have provided no evidence that the S.E.C. has investigated or acted upon,'' he wrote in a letter to Mary L. Schapiro, the commission chairwoman.

headline: Online Anticipation vs. Reality
summary: Despite the increasing emphasis movie studios and television networks place on Twitter feeds and Facebook fans, online buzz doesn't always deliver. Universal's ''Scott Pilgrim vs. the World'' and NBC's ''The Event'' are two of the most recent examples. But the Sundance Channel is crowing nonetheless about how the Facebook page for one of its shows - which will not have its premiere until next month - is running laps around those for heavily promoted network newcomers.

headline: Drug Benefit Managers Plan Merger
summary: Two of the nation's largest pharmacy benefit managers, Express Scripts and Medco Health Solutions, said on Thursday that they wanted to combine forces in a $29.1 billion merger that would account for about four of every 10 prescription claims in the country. If federal regulators and the companies' shareholders approve the deal, the merger would create a company with more than $100 billion in annual revenue. Analysts say the deal could fundamentally change the dynamics of the market for overseeing prescription drug use for health plans and employers, but they predicted that the merger would face the thorny issues of antitrust that have swirled around other ventures involving pharmacy benefit managers.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BELSON, MAXINE
summary: BELSON--Maxine. The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc. mourn the passing of Maxine Belson, wife of our good friend and faithful supporter, Jerome Belson. Our fondest thoughts and deepest condolences go out to Jerry and the entire Belson family. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn, Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan, President & Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

headline: Bill Cook, 80, Inventor of Medical Devices
summary: Bill Cook's first business venture -- selling shot glasses with pictures of nude women on the bottom -- flopped. But that did not stop him from developing a sprawling company that has made thousands of medical devices, including heart stents, urological equipment and living-tissue transplants. Along the way he amassed a $3.1 billion fortune, making him the 101st richest American in 2011, according to Forbes magazine. And yet he lived a modest life. He and his wife, Gayle, continued to live in the three-bedroom home they bought in 1967, having moved there from an apartment where they had used a spare bedroom to make a new sort of catheter.

headline: VMware Shows Its Cloud Strategy
summary: VMware made a handful of product announcements on Tuesday that add up to the company's bid to become the Microsoft of cloud computing. VMware, of course, is the leader in data center job-juggling technology called virtualization. This software not only makes data center computing more efficient -- less hardware, lower energy costs -- but it is a vital building block in the plumbing behind cloud computing.

headline: Short End of Stick For Buyout Barons
summary: It's not every day that the barons of the buyout industry find themselves on the shorter end of a sweet deal. But that's arguably the case in the turnaround of BankUnited, a relatively small Florida bank that's about to return to the public markets. John Kanas, who led the deal and runs the bank, is poised to collect nearly $100 million of the profits his private equity partners will make. That's an impressive feat given the caliber of the investors who backed him, a group that includes Carlyle, Blackstone, Wilbur Ross and the LeFrak family. But they won't be crying, either. All told, Mr. Kanas and BankUnited's financiers look set to turn a $940 million investment into a cool $2.8 billion or more, thanks to negotiating a bargain price when buying the bank from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in May 2009.

headline: Do You Want to Know All About Chromebooks? Just Ask
summary: Update Sunday, June 5 7:52 p.m.: Clarified that, while Chromebooks do have a hard drive, that drive is used by the OS, not for a user's data storage. Also changed wording to indicate that data is not in Google's possession, necessarily, but whichever cloud-based service a user is using. So Google's made a new laptop? Not exactly. Samsung and Acer have made new laptops called Chromebooks that run on Google's Chrome OS. They'll be available starting June 15 at Amazon.com and Best Buy.

headline: Rock Chronicle Inspires Battle Over Its Legacy
summary: Steve Baltin had been toiling as a freelance music writer for a decade when an entrepreneur named Jason Turner approached him a year ago about resurrecting Creem magazine, the irreverent and sardonic publication that defined rock in the 1970s. The offer to edit a once-famous magazine was tempting, to say the least. ''He talks a very good game, and he has these grand ambitions of creating this vast music network,'' Mr. Baltin said. ''I'm old enough to have grown up with Creem, and like many people who were hooked into this, I was excited about being involved.''

headline: Ins and Outs Of Calling Via the Net
summary: This week's e-mail bag brought a note that echoes the sentiments of many others: ''Hi David! Am I the only one getting really confused by all the free/cheap Internet calling options? Would you mind clearing the steadily occluding waters of Skype, Google Voice, Line2, FreePhone2Phone, and so on? Your fan, Caroline C.''

headline: An Online Strategy That Clicks
summary: Six years ago, after leaving a high-powered career in fashion sales to become a stay-at-home mother of very young children, Amy Gottesman found herself missing her income -- and looking for something to do when her kids were napping. So Ms. Gottesman, who lives on Long Island, put up a Web site under the name of Smash Party Entertainment, offering entertainment for parties, ranging from casinos to living Roman ''statues'' to murder mysteries. And then she waited for the business to come in -- which it didn't, even though she was advertising in local newspapers and mailing out coupons. After three months of staring at the phone, she decided to try $20 worth of pay-per-click advertising through Google's AdWords service, which placed her short ads alongside the search results for certain keywords, as well as on some Web pages with content related to those keywords. ''In a few days,'' she said, ''the phone started ringing.''

headline: Finding Advice Before Buying
summary: In an article in Monday's New York Times, ''Search Takes a Social Turn,'' Jenna Wortham details how turning to friends for product recommendations is the latest rage in the Web world, with a growing number of companies trying to capitalize on the trend and bring such information to product searches. For instance, as she described in the article, users of Facebook can choose to see their friends' favorite books on Amazon, specify in their profiles what products they like and informally poll friends on Facebook or Twitter for product recommendations. The article also details some downsides of plain old reviews online, including reliability issues.

headline: As Citi Revives, Chief Wins a Big Pay Deal
summary: 8:58 p.m. | Updated After spending years as one of Wall Street's lowest paid chief executives, Vikram S. Pandit received a $23.2 million retention package that could catapult him to the top of the list.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BELSON, MAXINE
summary: BELSON--Maxine. The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc. mourn the passing of Maxine Belson, wife of our good friend and faithful supporter, Jerome Belson. Our fondest thoughts and deepest condolences go out to Jerry and the entire Belson family. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn, Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan, President & Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

headline: A Big Loan From JPMorgan Is Evidence of Bank Muscle
summary: J.B. Reed/Bloomberg News Behind the scenes of AT&T's $39 billion bid for T-Mobile, a Wall Street giant left its mark on one of the biggest deals to emerge since the financial crisis.

headline: In Suit, City Accuses 32 Residents of Avoiding Millions in Cigarette Taxes
summary: New York City has filed a federal lawsuit against 32 residents it accused of ordering hundreds - and in some cases, thousands - of cartons of cigarettes online and reselling them illegally, avoiding millions of dollars in city cigarette taxes. The suit, filed on Wednesday, accuses the residents and Chavez Inc., a tobacco dealer based in Kentucky that sold tobacco products over the Internet, of violating the law by selling or conspiring to sell cigarettes without a New York City tax stamp between 2003 and 2009. Chavez was also named as a defendant.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GILL, JOHN LEE
summary: GILL--John Lee, of New York died August 10, 2011, at Chester River Manor. He was 88. He was born in Chestertown, Maryland, the son of the late Charles Lee Gill, Jr. and Mable Coppage Gill. Mr. Gill was preceded in death by his wife, T. Smyth Gill, and his brother, William Thomas Hepburn Gill. Survivors include his sister, Jean Gill Smith of Centreville, MD and several nieces and nephews. John was a Veteran of World War II, serving as a Naval Aviator in the Western Pacific, mainly on the USS Santee CVE 29. After the war he returned to Chestertown and completed Washington College and then served as a Special Agent, Federal Bureau of Investigation from 1951 to 1977, assigned to offices in the Midwest, West and New York City. He was an active volunteer with the New York City Fire Department, being honored as an Honorary Deputy Chief, Fire Department, New York and the USS Intrepid CV 19 Aircraft Carrier Museum where he was presented with a Seat of Honor aboard the Intrepid on Memorial Day 2011. Also, John was a member of The Fire Bell Club of New York, Entrepid Museum Volunteers, U.S. Naval Institute, Society of Former Special Agents of the FBI, Inc. and the Escort Carrier Sailors and Airmen Association. A Memorial Service will be held at 2pm, on September 24, 2011 at the Church of the Incarnation, 209 Madison Avenue (Corner of Madison and 35th Sts), New York, NY 10016 (Inquiries at 212-689-6350). In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations be made in memory of John to the New York Firefighters Burn Center Foundation, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx, New York, NY 10475 (718-379-1900).

headline: Another Tablet, but This One Shoots in 3-D
summary: Except for screen size, the first tablets on the market pretty much look alike: glass-faced slabs without much to set them apart. On the outside, the new Google G-Slate from T-Mobile isn't much of an exception. But it does have one distinction: On either side of a metal strip embossed with the Google logo are a pair of camera lenses. That's right, a pair. The G-Slate takes 720p HD movies in 3-D.

headline: Talk About Skyboxes: NFL Games on JetBlue
summary: Football fans who have to travel on Sundays have a reason to rejoice: it's now possible to watch live professional football at 30,000 feet above ground. JetBlue is the first commercial airline to offer DirecTV's NFL Sunday Ticket, which broadcasts up to 14 games played that day. The package, typically available to DirecTV subscribers, is available - free - for passengers flying to more than 50 JetBlue destinations.

headline: DealBook Online
summary: BUDGET REQUEST Gary Gensler, below, the top regulator of the derivatives industry, told lawmakers on Thursday that his agency needed more money to help prevent another financial crisis. In testimony before a House appropriations subcommittee, Mr. Gensler called the Commodity Futures Trading Commission ''a good investment for the American public, overseeing vast markets with a relatively small staff.'' Although the White House agrees with Mr. Gensler, Congressional Republicans are weighing severe cuts to the agency's budget. BEN PROTESS

headline: A Lack of Transparency In S.E.C. Disclosure Rule
summary: Joshua Roberts/Bloomberg NewsThe Securities and Exchange Commission headquarters.Has the Securities and Exchange Commission bungled its disclosure rules? That's the question being whispered around Wall Street trading floors after a series of company disclosures in recent weeks from the likes of Microsoft and Google that appear to have created an awful lot of confusion, potentially giving some savvy investors an edge while potentially putting the rest of us at a disadvantage.

headline: Online Tailor Raises Capital
summary: Bespoke clothing has been a luxury for the rich. But a men's e-commerce start-up, J. Hilburn, wants to use the Internet to make custom-made suits and shirts more affordable. On Thursday, J. Hilburn announced that it has raised $5 million from Bridgescale Partners and Battery Ventures, bringing its total venture capital to $13 million.

headline: Home Storage System Offers Automatic Remote Access
summary: Seagate has pulled off a remarkable feat: The company has integrated remote access to files stored on its new GoFlex Home Network Storage System so thoroughly and intelligently that it requires no setup. In fact, when testing the GoFlex Home network-attached storage (N.A.S.) drive, I called Seagate for technical support because I couldn't figure out how to set up remote access. I was never prompted to set up a dynamic DNS account, as other NAS drives do, and figured something was amiss.

headline: Just Say It And Search It
summary: Breakfast NY, an interactive advertising agency based in Brooklyn, is trying to get past the Web. Michael Lipton, one of the founders of the company, said marketing campaigns needed to be more creative than a simple site or would-be viral video to cut through the noise of everything else online.

headline: AT&T Makes Deal To Buy T-Mobile For $39 Billion
summary: 12:16 a.m. | Updated AT&T announced on Sunday that it had agreed to buy T-Mobile USA from Deutsche Telekom for $39 billion, in a deal that would create the largest carrier in the nation and promised to reshape the industry. The transaction - one of the largest since the onset of the financial crisis - is expected to start a fierce battle in Washington as regulators scrutinize the impact of the deal on competition and consumers. The deal would leave just three major cellular companies in the country: AT&T, Verizon and the much smaller Sprint Nextel.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ROBINSON, HENRIETTA T.
summary: ROBINSON--Henrietta Truesdell, passed away on June 27, 2011, after a short illness at the age of 95. Born in New York City on September 20, 1915, she was the daughter of Dr. Edward Delavan Truesdell, a surgeon, and the former Henrietta Norton. Mrs. Robinson graduated from Brearley School and Smith College. In 1941 she married Horace Brookes Blackwell Robinson, former partner at the law firm of Dewey Ballantine. She is survived by three children, Edward T. Robinson, Dr. Thomas D. Robinson, and J. Howland Robinson, and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Brick Church, Park Ave. at 91st St., at 3pm on Friday, July 29, 2011. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Brick Church, 62 E. 92nd St., New York, NY 10128, or US English Foundation, Inc., 1747 Pennsylvania Ave, NW, Suite 1050, Washington, DC 20006.

headline: NASA Tests Engine With an Uncertain Future
summary: One hundred fifty-four feet long, packed with 700 tons of propellant and anchored to the side of a Utah hill, a solid rocket motor developed for NASA's next generation of rockets is to unleash 3.6 million pounds of thrust in a test Tuesday morning. Whether this motor design will ever go anywhere is uncertain.

headline: Google's Coup Shifts Mobile Alliances: A History Of Interest In Handsets
summary: Back in 2004, Eric E. Schmidt, then Google's chief executive, proclaimed, ''We're not going into the phone business, but we're going to make sure Google is on those phones.'' Less than a year later, however, Google did the opposite.

headline: Allman Brothers Band May Revisit Old Haunt
summary: Is the Allman Brothers Band ready to end its rambling and return to the Beacon Theater? The hard-livin' Southern rock act was a mainstay at the Beacon, where its residencies at that Upper West Side concert hall had become an annual New York tradition and where the band played 190 shows over the past 20 years. In January the band announced that it had lost its home away from home to the Cirque du Soleil show ''Banana Shpeel,'' and would instead move its residency to the United Palace Theater in Washington Heights. (At the time, Gregg Allman, the band's co-founder and longtime lead singer, calmly remarked, ''It's a drag, but one monkey don't stop no show.'')

headline: Deal Joins a History of Antitrust Fights
summary: 6:38 p.m. | Updated AT&T's deal to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion is shaping up to be a heated regulatory battle.

headline: Motorola's Revival Includes an Entry in the Tablet Market
summary: 6:30 p.m. | Updated Adding more on the Xoom and other new products. LAS VEGAS -- Motorola, which has fought its way back into the cellphone market, is now taking on Apple's iPad.

headline: Live From the White House, a Twitter Town Hall
summary: The one thing that President Obama's Twitter town hall was not? A test of his ability to answer in 140 characters. For more than an hour, Mr. Obama took questions sent in via Twitter, but answered them the old fashioned way -- verbally.

headline: Golly, Another Way to Contact Friends in Twitter Land
summary: Smartphones are supposed to make calling easier, but between free calling apps like Google Voice, Skype, Fring, as well as services like Line2, there are a baffling collection of names and numbers remember. You may think the last thing we need is another way of contacting people (and you may be right), but a free service called Go800 is trying to make calling easy by replacing phone numbers with Twitter names.

headline: Restaurant Chain Turns to Employees for Creativity
summary: Editors' Note: With this issue, In Advertising returns for another year (its 10th). Because of the holiday for Martin Luther King's Birthday next Monday, please look for the next issue of In Advertising on Tuesday, Jan. 18. Many advertisers are using employees in their commercials. Others are sponsoring contests to create commercials. So it should come as no surprise that a restaurant chain is combining those trends.

headline: New President For Struggling Gap Inc. Unit
summary: The head of Gap North Americais leaving the company, one ofa number of changes that Gapannounced for its flagship brandafter years of declining sales atthe division.''Unless we put cute clothes infront of our customer on theshelf,'' said Art Peck, who willsucceed Marka Hansen as presidentof Gap North America, ''everythingelse we do isn't going tomatter.''Ms. Hansen, who has been atGap Inc. for 24 years, has run theGap North America divisionsince 2007. Though she had somenotable hits, like the revision ofthe denim line and the redesignof Gap's basic black pants, saleshave continued to drop.Mr. Peck, who has run the outletbusiness at Gap Inc. until now,will take over immediately. Thebrand will also create a new designhub, called the Global CreativeCenter, based in New York,which will combine design, productionand marketing under oneroof for the first time. Pam Wallack,currently the president ofGap Adult North America, willbecome the head of that unit.And the Gap stores will have anew ad agency, Ogilvy & MatherWorldwide, along with tapping anOgilvy executive, Seth Farbman,to become the new global chiefmarketing officer.The company had a marketingsnafu in the fall when it introduceda new Gap logo, designedin part by its former agency,Laird & Partners. The classiclogo, with a navy backgroundand tall, thin letters, was replacedby a white background with atiny blue square and a thick sansseriffont. Consumers objected tothe new logo on social networkingsites, and within days, Gapwent back to the original.''I expect more from our Gapbusiness in North America,''Glenn K. Murphy, chief executiveof Gap Inc., said in a statement.Analysts said a change at thedivision was due.''It has struggled over the past10 years,'' said Paul Lejuez, an analystwith Nomura Securities.Gap North America has notposted an annual increase insales at stores open at least ayear since 2004. In the first 11months of the 2010 fiscal year,even as retail in general bouncedback, sales at Gap North Americawere down 1 percent.And overall sales at the divisionhave decreased every yearfor the last five years. In 2009,sales were $3.82 billion, down almostone-third from where theywere in 2004.''They've closed a ton of storesover the past several years, butthey've not seen a boost in compsas a result -- you would thinkthat some sales would transfer toother existing Gap stores, butthat's not happening, and thattells you something,'' Mr. Lejuezsaid.The problem, analysts said, isthat people don't want the clothingthat Gap is selling.''They stand for these keyitems that are fairly basic in nature,and quite frankly, it's toughto keep recreating what are somefairly fundamental items insomebody's closet,'' said AdrienneTennant, an analyst withJanney Capital Markets. ''Ajean's a jean.''John D. Morris, an analyst atBMO Capital Markets, noted thatthe spring clothing did not lookmuch more promising.The spring merchandise is''uncompelling and not resonatingwith the brand's target market,''he said in a note to clients.Also, ''the company brought intoo much spring too early,'' leadingto markdowns even on newarrivals.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths DEPODWIN, HORACE J.
summary: DePODWIN--Horace John, 87 of Pompton Plains, NJ died Tuesday, October 5, 2010. Born October 28, 1922, Brooklyn, NY to Thaddeus and Lena (Kornat) Podwin. Horace served as Sergeant Major, U.S. Army, 85th Mountain Infantry Regiment, 2nd Battalion, 10th Mt. Division, 1942-1946, Bronze Star. Attended Middlebury College, B.A.; Columbia University, Ph.D. economics, 1953. He started his career as Manager, Economic Research, General Electric Company and was a consultant to President John F. Kennedy's administration, General Agreement on Tariffs & Trade. Horace was the President of Horace J. DePodwin Associates Co., Inc./ Economic Studies, Inc., from 1963-2005. He was also Dean of Rutgers University Graduate School of Management, 1966-1982. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Carolyn (Ohlander) formerly of Maplewood, NJ, three loving children: Andrew H., Margaret D. Harwood, and David A.; six grandchildren: Kevin S. DePodwin, Karen B. San Giacomo, Daniel A. and Michael T. DePodwin, John H. and Maggie B. Harwood. He is also survived by his sister, Rita Fink. Horace was predeceased by his sister Lucille Mulvihill. His family, friends, and business associates will remember him for his high intellect and sense of purpose, droll sense of humor, firm handshake, love for the outdoors (especially skiing), craftsmanship, integrity, generosity and public service. He was a giant to fellow mankind who he served with honor. A memorial service will be held 11am on Wednesday, October 13th, at the Wyoming Presbyterian Church, 432 S. Wyoming Ave., Millburn, NJ. For further information please contact Gallaway & Crane Funeral Home at 908-766-0250 or to light a candle to leave a message for the family visit gcfuneralhome.com. In lieu of flowers, donations are asked to be made to: Horace J. DePodwin Scholarship Fund, c/o Rutgers University Foundation, attn.: Terri Suarez, RBS Dev. Office, One Washington Park, Newark, NJ 07102; or 10th Mountain Division Hut Association, 1280 Ute Ave., Suite 21, Aspen, CO 81611.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GARRETT, GUY T.
summary: GARRETT--Guy Thomas, Jr. A resident of Buffalo Junction, VA for over twenty years, departed this life on Monday, February 7, 2011 in Cary, NC. Guy Garrett was born in Peekskill, NY on June 7, 1932, the eldest of four sons of the late Guy Thomas Garrett, Sr. and the late Annie Garrett Williams. Mr. Garrett graduated from Howard University in Washington, D.C. in 1954 with a degree in Political Science. In 1955, he married Geraldyne Baker and from that union, two children were born, a daughter, Lynn, and son, Guy, III. Following college, Mr. Garrett served in the US Army for three years as an infantry officer. After his military service, he returned to New York City and held a series of positions of increasing responsibility. He taught in the New York City School system, was a branch manager for Household Finance, and managed the personnel department at the Long Island Lighting Company. Mr. Garrett joined the New York Times Company in 1974 as Director of Personnel. He was elected Vice President of Personnel of The Times Company in July 1976 and served in that capacity until he retired in 1988. Guy Garrett was a long service member of the March of Dimes Board of Trustees in its New York Chapter. Throughout his life, Mr. Garrett used his leadership skills in the service of God. He was a faithful member of Wharton Memorial Baptist Church in Nelson, VA where he served for more than twenty years as a Deacon. He was bestowed the honorable status of Deacon Emeritus in April 2007. Mr. Garrett is survived by his two children, Lynn Henderson Harris and Guy Garrett, III, both of Durham, NC; a daughter-in-law, Linda Burdine Garrett; a brother, William Garrett of Oklahoma City, OK; four grandchildren, Kira Henderson of Macon, GA, Otis Henderson, Priscilla Garrett, and Shirley Garrett, all of Durham; one great-grandchild, Michael Henderson of Macon, GA, and a host of other relatives and friends who cherish his memory. He was preceded in death by his brothers, James Garrett and Arnold Garrett and a son-in-law, Lucious Harris. A Celebration of Life service will be held on Saturday, February 12, 2011, at 11:00am at Wharton Memorial Baptist Church at 57 White House Road in Nelson, VA. The service will be preceded by a visitation from 10:00 to 11:00am in the church sanctuary. The family requests that friends and family consider making a donation in Mr. Garrett's honor to Alzheimers North Carolina, Inc. in lieu of sending flowers (1305 Navaho Drive, Suite 101, Raleigh, NC 27609; telephone 919-832-3732 or 1-800-228-8738). Should a gift of flowers be preferred, the family florist is Avenue Florist in Clarksville, VA; 434-738-8888.

headline: Where Home Prices Are Cut
summary: Updated | Sept. 15, 2010 Among the 50 most populated cities in the United States, Minneapolis has the highest percentage of actively listed nonforeclosed homes that have had at least one price cut since first going on the market, according to new data released Wednesday from the real estate site Trulia.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths DEPODWIN, HORACE JOHN
summary: DePODWIN--Horace John, 87 of Pompton Plains, NJ died Tuesday, October 5, 2010. Born October 28, 1922, Brooklyn, NY to Thaddeus and Lena (Kornat) Podwin. Horace served as Sergeant Major, U.S. Army, 85th Mountain Infantry Regiment, 2nd Battalion, 10th Mt. Division, 1942-1946, Bronze Star. Attended Middlebury College, B.A.; Columbia University, Ph.D. economics, 1953. He started his career as Manager, Economic Research, General Electric Company and was a consultant to President John F. Kennedy's administration, General Agreement on Tariffs & Trade. Horace was the President of Horace J. DePodwin Associates Co., Inc./ Economic Studies, Inc., from 1963-2005. He was also Dean of Rutgers University Graduate School of Management, 1966-1982. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Carolyn (Ohlander) formerly of Maplewood, NJ, three loving children: Andrew H., Margaret D. Harwood, and David A.; six grandchildren: Kevin S. DePodwin, Karen B. San Giacomo, Daniel A. and Michael T. DePodwin, John H. and Maggie B. Harwood. He is also survived by his sister, Rita Fink. Horace was predeceased by his sister Lucille Mulvihill. His family, friends, and business associates will remember him for his high intellect and sense of purpose, droll sense of humor, firm handshake, love for the outdoors (especially skiing), craftsmanship, integrity, generosity and public service. He was a giant to fellow mankind who he served with honor. A memorial service will be held 11am on Wednesday, October 13th, at the Wyoming Presbyterian Church, 432 S. Wyoming Ave., Millburn, NJ. For further information please contact Gallaway & Crane Funeral Home at 908-766-0250 or to light a candle to leave a message for the family visit gcfuneralhome.com. In lieu of flowers, donations are asked to be made to: Horace J. DePodwin Scholarship Fund, c/o Rutgers University Foundation, attn.: Terri Suarez, RBS Dev. Office, One Washington Park, Newark, NJ 07102; or 10th Mountain Division Hut Association, 1280 Ute Ave., Suite 21, Aspen, CO 81611.

headline: Questions, And Directors, Lost in the Ether
summary: ANNUAL shareholder meetings may not be the most efficient occasion for managers to meet with the owners of the companies they run -- they can be hard for shareholders to get to and are sometimes hijacked by gadflies with personal agendas and long-winded, irrelevant questions. Because most, if not all, shareholders cast their votes before the meetings even take place, they can feel ritualistic and not terribly meaningful. Yet, these congregations do give shareholders a rare opportunity to take the measure of the managers and directors who are supposed to work for them. How executives answer questions that shareholders pitch at them can be very revealing.

headline: Consumer Group Aims at Google
summary: Consumer Watchdog, a consumer group, has long been critical of Google and some of the comments that Eric Schmidt, the company's chief executive, has made about privacy online. On Thursday, the group took its objections to a new level with a 540-square-foot video advertisement in Times Square in New York that shows Mr. Schmidt as an unctuous ice cream truck driver who knows everything about everyone and happily offers free ice cream in exchange for full body scans. (The video is available on YouTube, which is owned by Google.)

headline: Weighing Value Of iPhone Cachet
summary: Apple sold more than 16 million iPhones in the last quarter, according to its earnings report. Next month sales will surely continue to rise as Apple starts selling the iPhone on the Verizon network. But if Apple wants to fend off the iPhone's rivals, will it have to sell its signature mobile device on other networks as well? Some analysts say yes. The iPhone's fiercest competitor is Google's Android platform, in phones that are available on all the major United States carriers.

headline: Transit Benefit Faces Cutback
summary: Last year, as part of the stimulus package, Congress nearly doubled the maximum amount workers could deduct from their paychecks, before taxes, to apply toward monthly mass transit commuting costs. That meant rail and bus commuters could deduct the same amount each month as commuters who drive and pay for parking. But if Congress doesn't act soon, the increase for mass transit riders to $230 a month is set to expire at the end of the year, and the benefit will return to $120 a month.

headline: Inquiries May Bring Big Fines, Banks Say
summary: Several big banks warned investors on Friday that they could face sizable financial penalties as a result of state and federal investigations into abusive mortgage practices. The disclosures by Bank of America, Wells Fargo and Citigroup came after a furor late last year over how foreclosures were being conducted.

headline: A Manic Robot Puts a Twist on a Classic Card Game
summary: Remember the card game Uno? Now, Uno remembers you. To celebrate the 40th anniversary of the game, Mattel developed Uno Roboto, an interactive, computerized version that records the names of the players and their house rule.

headline: Apple Unveils Design for New Office
summary: It's well known that Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, has had a hand in the design of just about everything Apple makes, including the Macs, MacBooks, iMacs, iPods, iTunes, iPhones, iPads and, now, the iCloud. So we can only imagine that Mr. Jobs had a say about the look and feel of what tech bloggers are already calling the iSpaceship: a proposed ring-shaped building that would house as many as 13,000 Apple employees not far from the company's current headquarters in Cupertino, Calif.

headline: For Verizon, Little Cause To Be Worried
summary: 7:39 p.m. | Updated As AT&T seeks to become the nation's biggest cellphone service provider by buying T-Mobile USA for $39 billion, many eyes are now turned to the company that currently holds that title, Verizon Wireless.

headline: Citi Changing Check Process
summary: Citibank says it will change the way it processes customers' checks, a move that could result in fewer fees for bounced checks for account holders. Customers are being notified this week in their bank statement mailings that as of July 25, the bank will process checks in order of ''low to high''-that is, it will pay checks in order of smallest dollar amount to the largest. Currently, Citibank - as do most banks - pays checks in order of highest dollar amount to the lowest. The thinking has been that big checks are often covering important bills like mortgage or car payments.

headline: Amazon Debate: Android or Not?
summary: Waiting for Amazon to sell a full-fledged tablet feels like waiting for the grass to grow: we know it's going to happen, but it's taking an awfully long time. As we have reported over the last year, Amazon has been readying a color screen tablet that will run the Google Android operating system. Jeff Bezos, Amazon's chief executive, has even acknowledged that a tablet project is in the works, saying earlier this year that the company was actively working on a ''multipurpose tablet device.''

headline: Yahoo and Alibaba Reach An Agreement on Alipay
summary: 7:32 p.m. | Updated After a simmering feud that reached soap opera proportions, Yahoo and the Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet company it partly owns, have reached an agreement over a Chinese payments processing company.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths PATRICOLA, JOANNE ROSE
summary: PATRICOLA--Joanne Rose, died suddenly on Thursday, October 21, 2010 in Hudson, FL. She was 68 years old. Born January 4, 1942 she was the beloved daughter of the late Lawrence and Erminia Piscani Patricola and the dear sister of Salvatore. She was also the loving aunt of Larry, Anthony, Carmela and Sal and the beloved friend of Dr. Marion T. DiFiglia. She graduated from St. Nicholas Tolentine High School, Bronx, NY in 1959, receiving a nursing degree from Nassau Community College and completed her post graduate work at Iona College. Her nursing career included the fields of ob-gyn, surgery, medicine and psychiatric nursing. From 1978 to 1981 she served as head of the dialysis program at Our Lady of Mercy Hospital, Bronx, NY. She ended her career as a nurse and manager in private practice with her retirement in 2008. A Funeral Mass will be offered Thursday, 10:30am at St. John the Baptist Church, Yonkers, NY. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. The family will receive visitors on Wednesday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 732 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, NY 10704. 914-375-1400 www.ruggieroandsonsfh.com

headline: Kids, Inc.
summary: PERHAPS the biggest perk of being a fashion designer is not the ability to design for yourself but for your children. Just ask Stella McCartney. The designer is about to bring her fourth child into the world, and introduce a collection on Wednesday specifically for the 12-and-under set. Pieces like cashmere-blend pea jackets and floral dresses are designed to be affordable (the line is priced from $20 for T-shirts to $155 for jackets) and timeless so that you don't have to choose between dressing your children well and sending them to college. Still, Ms. McCartney knows that as fashion consumers go, children are as fickle as anyone. ''My daughter is 3 and deep in the pink thing,'' she said, ''and I have to remind myself she will probably hate it in six months.'' ALIX BROWNE

headline: The View From Behind the Wheel of a Tiny Toy Racer
summary: The Hot Wheels Video Racer, from Mattel, is a standard-sized Hot Wheels car that is packed with electronics, including a front-view camera, built-in LCD screen, mini-USB port and a rechargeable battery. It costs $60. So what can it do that a traditional 99-cent Hot Wheels car can't? Think of it as a tiny rolling camcorder, complete with a preview screen on the bottom.

headline: Reading Bin Laden and His World
summary: Since 9/11, there has been an outpouring of books about Osama bin Laden, Al Qaeda, the Sept. 11 attacks and the war in Afghanistan. Below is an annotated list of some of the more useful ones.Some of these books are primarily concerned with giving the reader a bildungsroman-like account of Bin Laden's transformation into a charismatic leader from a callow young man who ''couldn't lead eight ducks across the street,'' as Prince Bandar, the former Saudi ambassador in Washington, once said. They underscore the unresolved Oedipal problems (not unlike those of George W. Bush) that he had with his powerful and wealthy father, while exploring the role that older mentors played in his growing radicalization. ''The Bin Ladens,'' by Steve Coll, also adds new details to our understanding of how the young Bin Laden evolved from a loyal family adjutant into an angry black sheep lashing out at some of the very connections his father and brothers had cultivated in their business dealings for years.

headline: Ashland to Acquire International Specialty
summary: 8:19 p.m. | Updated Ashland, the maker of Valvoline motor oil, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy the specialty chemical company International Specialty Products for $3.2 billion in cash.

headline: Actors' Union Last Obstacle for Jackson's 'Hobbit'
summary: 1:43 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES-Apparently, only an ongoing union dispute in New Zealand now stands between ''The Hobbit'' and a start date in February. Warner Brothers' New Line Cinema unit and MGM have worked out their deal to finance the pair of films to be based on J. R. R. Tolkien's novel, and Peter Jackson's deal to direct is now finalized, according to a person who was briefed on the movie's intricacies this week. But continuing uncertainty over attempts to have the filmmakers bargain collectively with their actors in New Zealand still stands between the production and its planned February start date (already delayed from an anticipated January date). New Zealand officials have said the production can't legally enter a collective bargaining arrangement with its actor-contractors, but unions there have insisted that a deal could be struck. If the studios move the film out of New Zealand, the budget, which already runs into the hundreds of millions of dollars, would have to be redrawn, and at least some further delay would be inevitable.

headline: The AT&T Deal and the Wireless Business
summary: An outlook on the wireless industry and an opinion on the aggressive move AT&T has made to pick up T-Mobile, with telecom legend John Stanton, Clearwire interim CEO and chairman.

headline: Jobs Steps Down. Saying He Cannot Meet His Duties
summary: SAN FRANCISCO -- Steven P. Jobs, whose insistent vision that he knew what consumers wanted made Apple one of the world's most valuable and influential companies, is stepping down as chief executive, the company announced late Wednesday. ''I have always said that if there ever came a day when I could no longer meet my duties and expectations as Apple's C.E.O., I would be the first to let you know,'' Mr. Jobs said in a letter released by the company. ''Unfortunately, that day has come.''

headline: @Sandra Bernhard
summary: Tweeting Since April 2009Followers 57, 545Twitter Bio Actress, author, personality, singer Sandra Bernhard's Twitter-worthy notions start out a lot like anyone else's. ''I'll be walking down the street,'' she said, ''and I see something or a funny idea pops into my head.'' But instead of composing a message on the spot, she performs a ritual of social-media restraint, she said: ''I keep repeating it, then I run home and send it out!''

headline: A New Facebook App That Eases the Way for iPad Users
summary: Facebook has had a mobile app for some time, but iPad users have had to go without a native iPad app. Yes, you could access Facebook through the iPad's Safari Web browser or used the iPhone app on the iPad, but both of those options come with compromises: Facebook's Web site is not optimized for a touchscreen and the company's iPhone app is simply magnified (and blurrier) on an iPad.

headline: Amazon Fights California Sales Tax
summary: Californians will have to start paying sales tax on their purchases from Amazon.com starting Friday after Gov. Jerry Brown signed legislation earlier this week requiring online retailers to collect the tax. At least, that is what California's tax authority says.

headline: Taking the Nonunion Route
summary: After numerous failed attempts to unionize Wal-Mart stores, the nation's main union for retail workers has decided to try a different approach: it has helped create a new, nonunion group of Wal-Mart employees that intends to press for better pay, benefits and most of all, more respect at work. The group, Organization United for Respect at Walmart, or OUR Walmart for short, says it has quietly signed up thousands of members in recent months, and it is going public this week with a Web site, ourwalmart.org, and a Facebook page. Organizers say they have more than 50 members at some stores, and they hope to soon have tens of thousands of members. Wal-Mart has nearly 1.4 million workers nationwide.

headline: U.S. Inquiry Into Google Has Search As Its Focus
summary: Google confirmed on Friday that the Federal Trade Commission had opened an antitrust investigation into its core search and advertising business. The inquiry has the potential to turn into the biggest showdown between the United States government and a major technology company since the Microsoft antitrust trial that began in the late 1990s.

headline: On Twitter, Lady Gaga Promotes Her Material
summary: Ever the provocateur, Lady Gaga posted a picture of herself on her Web site, dancing with her blonde hair flying in the wind and wearing nothing but a ''Born This Way'' jacket. The image follows her first Twitter posting of 2011 in which she announced that her new single, ''Born This Way,'' will be available in stores on Feb. 13 and that the album of the same name will be for sale on May 23. The announcement should come as no surprise to Lady Gaga followers; she had already posted on Twitter a few samplings of the lyrics from the song: ''Don't hide yourself in regret, just love yourself and you're set. I'm on the right track baby, I was born this way.''

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: PETER SELLERSThroughout his career Sellers (1925-80) maintained that he had no personality and that, like an empty pitcher, he was waiting to be filled by his latest character. Or, as Bette Davis once put it, ''He isn't an actor, he's a chameleon.'' The final installment in this tribute begins with ''Man in a Cocked Hat'' (1959), starring Sellers as Prime Minister Amphibulos. ''Being There'' (1979), in which he portrays an illiterate gardener mistaken for a media genius and transformed into a national hero, follows at 9:45; in ''Dr. Strangelove, or How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb'' (1964), a British officer (Sellers, who also plays the president of the United States and his physicist adviser, a former Nazi, above) orders an air strike against Russia, at midnight; and ''Lolita'' (1962), Vladimir Nabokov's classic about an aging intellectual (James Mason) in love with a teenager (Sue Lyon), with Sellers as the amoral screenwriter Clare Quilty, at 1:45 a.m. 7 P.M. (13, 49) PBS NEWSHOUR Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. discusses issues raised in President Obama's State of the Union address.

headline: With Deal, EBay Shifts To Big Retail
summary: 9:56 p.m. | Updated EBay, synonymous with second-hand wares, is seeking a new retail identity.

headline: LivingSocial Chief Races to Escape Shadow of Larger Rival
summary: Last summer, Tim O'Shaughnessy drafted a fictional article, entitled ''How LivingSocial Won the Local Commerce Space.'' In 1,500 words, the chief executive of LivingSocial spun a tale about how his site had fiercely battled its rival Groupon and emerged the victor. He dated the essay July 2012.

headline: Creating a Facebook Group So Private That It's a Secret
summary: I recently joined an amateur music group whose members set up a Facebook group. Two days into the project, one member panicked. ''All my friends can see everything we're talking about,'' she wrote us via e-mail. ''I don't want them to even know I'm doing this. We need to go back to e-mail.'' You don't. Facebook has a privacy setting for groups that allows you to hide not only the group's activity, but its very existence. To set it, you need to be configured as an admin for the group. By default, the only admin for a group is the Facebook member who created it.

headline: Watch the Wabbit, Watch the Wabbit
summary: CERTAIN cultural phrases become so embedded in our subconscious that they will interrupt our own final rites. Maybe you hear whispers of Dickinson when sandwiched in a packed subway. (''I'm nobody! Who are you?/Are you nobody, too?'') Maybe a jolt of Shakespearean bravado sounds in your head as you join the line at Dunkin' Donuts (''We few, we happy few, we band of brothers.'') Or maybe, like me, you stare into the morning mirror to be greeted with: ''What a maroon!''

headline: 'Hangover 2' Settles Suit From Artist Over Tattoo
summary: A lawsuit by a Missouri tattoo artist that threatened to stop the distribution of the blockbuster sequel ''Hangover Part II'' has been settled, the movie's studio, Warner Brothers Entertainment, announced this week. The tattoo artist, S. Victor Whitmill, had gone to Federal District Court in St. Louis in April to argue that Warner Brothers had failed to get his permission to use his design for a face tattoo, created in 2003 for the boxer Mike Tyson, on one of the central characters in the movie.

headline: A Photoshop Tool Surprises Even Its Developers
summary: The newest version of Adobe Photoshop, CS5, has some pretty tricky tools, and at least one that the developers at Adobe didn't know about. But it's a surprise that can come in handy. The new tool is called content aware fill. What it does is to allow you to remove an unwanted element from a photo and to automatically fill the spot with a background that matches the rest of the photo.

headline: Tricks to Get An iPad 2 Quickly
summary: So you want an iPad 2. So do a lot of other people. At first glance it might seem that you're completely out of luck. Apple's Web site says the wait for a new iPad 2 is four to five weeks, up from just three to four weeks on Monday. Going to an Apple store likely won't work either as most retail outlets are completely out of inventory.

headline: AT&T's Cost For Getting T-Mobile
summary: ''We have never seen a deal with more regulatory risk be attempted in the U.S.'' That was the initial assessment of AT&T's $39 billion agreement to acquire T-Mobile, from Jonathan Chaplin, one of the most thoughtful telecommunications analysts on Wall Street.

headline: Ad Texts, Tailored to Location
summary: On Monday, AT&T will announce the company's first location-based marketing service through which brands can send text messages to users who choose to receive special offers. The service, called ShopAlerts by AT&T, will send users messages from brand partners including Hewlett-Packard, Kmart, JetBlue and S. C. Johnson. The company is working with Placecast, which supplies a technology known as geo-fencing that allows retailers to send messages to users in a defined geographic area.

headline: In Letters to F.C.C., Big Names in Technology Back AT&T's Bid for T-Mobile
summary: In its quest to win approval of its $39 billion takeover of T-Mobile USA, AT&T just got a lot of help from its friends. Eight technology giants, including Facebook and Microsoft, and 10 venture capital firms, filed letters supporting the acquisition late on Monday. The letters, filed with the Federal Communications Commission, lent their support to AT&T's argument that the T-Mobile deal will help the company extend its next-generation data network across the country, helping to meet the growing need for wireless broadband services.

headline: Israeli Archive Gets Help Putting Holocaust Stories at Fingertips
summary: TEL AVIV -- When Google, the world's largest search engine, joined forces with Yad Vashem, keeper of the world's largest Holocaust archive, the first thing one Google employee here did was search for his grandfather's name. A link took the employee, Doron Avni, to a Google-operated page on the Yad Vashem Web site showing a photograph of his grandfather, Yecheskel Fleischer, taken in 1941 just after he was released from a Nazi-run prison in Lithuania.

headline: New Capital For Groupon Sets Stage For Offering
summary: The 30-year-old founder and chief executive of Groupon, Andrew Mason, could raise as much as $950 million from investors in the next few weeks, laying the groundwork for a multibillion-dollar initial public offering in 2011. The social buying site, which offers coupons for local businesses, has so far locked up $500 million in fresh capital from Fidelity Investments, Morgan Stanley, T. Rowe Price, and other large investors - allowing Mr. Mason and eight other directors to take a significant amount of cash off the table.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths PATRICOLA, JOANNE
summary: PATRICOLA--Joanne Rose, died suddenly on Thursday, October 21, 2010 in Hudson, FL. She was 68 years old. Born January 4, 1942 she was the beloved daughter of the late Lawrence and Erminia Piscani Patricola and the dear sister of Salvatore. She was also the loving aunt of Larry, Anthony, Carmela and Sal and the beloved friend of Dr. Marion T. DiFiglia. She graduated from St. Nicholas Tolentine High School, Bronx, NY in 1959, receiving a nursing degree from Nassau Community College and completed her post graduate work at Iona College. Her nursing career included the fields of ob-gyn, surgery, medicine and psychiatric nursing. From 1978 to 1981 she served as head of the dialysis program at Our Lady of Mercy Hospital, Bronx, NY. She ended her career as a nurse and manager in private practice with her retirement in 2008. A Funeral Mass will be offered Thursday, 10:30am at St. John the Baptist Church, Yonkers, NY. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. The family will receive visitors on Wednesday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 732 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, NY 10704. 914-375-1400 www.ruggieroandsonsfh.com

headline: F.C.C. Faces Challenges To Net Rules
summary: 8:52 p.m. | Updated Want to watch hours of YouTube videos or sort through Facebook photos on the computer? Your Internet providers would be forbidden from blocking you under rules approved by the Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday. But if you want to do the same on your cellphone, you may not have the same protections. The debate over the rules, intended to preserve open access to the Internet, seems to have resulted in a classic Washington solution - the kind that pleases no one on either side of the issue. Verizon and other service providers would prefer no government involvement. Public interest advocates think the rules stop far short of ensuring free speech. Some Republicans believe the rules are another instance of government overreach.

headline: Citigroup, Profit Up, Increases Investment
summary: 8:43 p.m. | Updated For two and a half years, Vikram S. Pandit was forced to hunker down to fix Citigroup's troubled businesses and fend off the bank's critics in Washington.

headline: CBS Explores Live Streaming With Web Show
summary: The live Web show ''What's Trending'' at cbsnews.com, an attempt to build a news-and-chat program driven by social networking -- sort of a digital ''Today'' -- is a self-consciously experimental project. That self-consciousness registers throughout the half-hour show; it rang through clearly in the premiere episode last Tuesday, when the host, the blogger and online reporter Shira Lazar, announced: ''We are all about the trending topics and stories the world is sharing. It's what you need to know to be in the now.'' What's obviously different about ''What's Trending,'' which will webcast its second episode Tuesday at 1 p.m. Eastern time, is its approach to the news -- its content and format -- an area in which it's already been taken to task. It's probably unfair, or at least unrealistic, to criticize the show for a lack of seriousness or news judgment, given its premise and its Twitter-driven title. In the premiere episode the struggle by Ms. Lazar and her producers to find an intelligent way to discuss current events through the lenses of Facebook and Twitter (here, as in most discussions, the alpha and omega of social networking) was palpable and mostly unsuccessful.

headline: The iPhone Challenge
summary: The Times's personal technology editor travels far and wide to see whether Verizon's iPhone really does work better than the competition.

headline: Already Third, Sprint Would Fall Farther Behind
summary: With AT&T agreeing to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion, the future of Sprint Nextel just got fuzzier. Over the past several months, Sprint had held its own talks with Deutsche Telekom, the owner of T-Mobile, over a potential deal, as part of an effort to gain sorely needed scale and wireless spectrum, according to people with knowledge of the talks, which were intended to be private. But Telekom's discussions with AT&T moved more quickly this month, and the two reached a preliminary agreement last week, one of these people said.

headline: An App Tracks Your Run With Maps and Times
summary: Runners on a budget don't have to spend hundreds of dollars for a GPS unit or watch that will accurately record their distance and time on a run, provided they have already spent hundreds on an iPhone. A new $1.99 app from Nike uses the iPhone's GPS and mapping capabilities to track a runner's performance.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ZIELINSKI, EDWARD A.
summary: ZIELINSKI--Edward A., on June 1st, 2011, he had a long distinguished career in information technology, affiliated over the years with Lucent, AT&T and Pfizers, Inc. Survived by his brothers Richard and Robert. Memorial services to be announced at a later date.

headline: Abracadabra! Magic Trumps Math
summary: Over a decade ago, Internet companies promoted new ways to measure their business performance, introducing concepts like ''eyeballs'' and ''mindshare'' to investors. Now the latest wave of Internet start-ups are adding their own particular yardsticks to the valuation vocabulary.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ROBINSON, HENRIETTA TRUESDELL
summary: ROBINSON--Henrietta Truesdell, passed away on June 27, 2011, after a short illness at the age of 95. Born in New York City on September 20, 1915, she was the daughter of Dr. Edward Delavan Truesdell, a surgeon, and the former Henrietta Norton. Mrs. Robinson graduated from Brearley School and Smith College. In 1941 she married Horace Brookes Blackwell Robinson, former partner at the law firm of Dewey Ballantine. She is survived by three children, Edward T. Robinson, Dr. Thomas D. Robinson, and J. Howland Robinson, and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Brick Church, Park Ave. at 91st St., at 3pm on Friday, July 29, 2011. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Brick Church, 62 E. 92nd St., New York, NY 10128, or US English Foundation, Inc., 1747 Pennsylvania Ave, NW, Suite 1050, Washington, DC 20006.

headline: Sheen Loses Bid to Block Arbitration
summary: The court fight between Charlie Sheen, Warner Brothers and the producer Chuck Lorre is on, for real. In a Santa Monica courtroom this morning, Judge Jacqueline A. Connor of Los Angeles Superior Court turned down a last-minute request for a temporary restraining order that would have blocked the dispute from being sent to arbitration by JAMS/Endispute, a mediation firm. The request for arbitration was made by Warner, invoking what it said it believed to be a contractual right.

headline: Checking Purchases On iTunes
summary: Q.Is there any way to see a list of specific items billed to an iTunes Store account, no matter which computer they were bought on?A.The Account Information page for each iTunes Store account keeps a sales record. To get there quickly, open iTunes and click on the iTunes Store link on the left side of the window. On the right side of the Store window click the Account link, type in your name and password, and click the Account Info button. On the Account Information page, click the Purchase History button to see a list of all the songs, apps, videos and other items purchased from the iTunes Store. The list can be helpful if you suspect you may have unauthorized purchases (from sneaky family members or otherwise) on your credit-card bill. You can also use the Report a Problem button on the page to file a complaint about a file that isn't working properly.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LYNCH, T. PATRICK
summary: LYNCH--Rev. T. Patrick., S.J., on February 28, 2011. Beloved brother of Father Edward C. Lynch, S.J. and Sister Barbara M. Lynch, SSJ. Reposing March 2nd, at St. Peter's College Chapel at St. Peter's Hall, 2652 Kennedy Blvd, Jersey City, NJ from 1:30-3:30pm, followed by a wake service at Murray Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 E. Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY, 7-9pm. Mass of Resurrection on Thursday, March 3rd at 11:30am at Murray Weigel Hall Chapel. Burial at the Jesuit Martyrs Shrine Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. For further information contact Farenga Bros. Inc. Directors, (718)654-0500.

headline: Google's Groupon Gambit
summary: Google's $6 billion bid for Groupon, an online coupon start-up, is an aggressive move by the company to dominate local online advertising and help with its long-sought move into social networking. Google has offered Groupon $5.3 billion, with the promise of $700 million in performance bonuses for management, according to a person knowledgeable about the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Several people close to the deal said Groupon, which is based in Chicago, was expected to approve the acquisition and an agreement could be signed as early as this week.

headline: Year of the Tablet, Take 2?
summary: Last year, as 2009 came to a close, I wrote a blog post predicting that 2010 would be the ''Year of the Tablet.'' This was several months before the Apple iPad was announced by Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive. I said then that 2010 would bring a number of tablet computers to the market, including innovative products from Apple, Microsoft, Google and other PC manufacturers, that would change the face of computing and the way we consume magazines, newspapers, video and other Web content.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LYNCH, REV. T. PATRICK.
summary: LYNCH--Rev. T. Patrick.,S.J., on February 28, 2011. Beloved brother of Father Edward C. Lynch, S.J. and Sister Barbara M. Lynch, SSJ. Reposing March 2nd, at St. Peter's College Chapel at St. Peter's Hall, 2652 Kennedy Blvd, Jersey City, NJ from 1:30-3:30pm, followed by a wake service at Murray Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 E. Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY, 7-9pm. Mass of Resurrection on Thursday, March 3rd at 11:30am at Murray Weigel Hall Chapel. Burial at the Jesuit Martyrs Shrine Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. For further information contact Farenga Bros. Inc. Directors, (718)654-0500.

headline: The New It Sneaker
summary: A SNEAKER'S style quotient can usually be expressed as a function of its retro charm, and an inverse of its underlying technology. So it's surprising that the It shoe gracing the feet of the fashion set is the Nike Free, a high-performance running shoe. As Nike's answer to the barefoot-running movement, the Free aims to biomechanically mimic an unencumbered stride.

headline: Netflix Android App Leaves Many Users on the Sidelines
summary: Movie-rental and streaming company Netflix announced today that it had a streaming app for Android. The iOS app for Apple devices was released in 2010, but now users of Google's mobile operating system can watch the thousands of movies and TV shows that are available for instant online viewing. Well, not all of Android users. As MobileCrunch reported, compatible smartphones at this point are HTC's Incredible, Nexus One, Evo 4G and G2. The Samsung Nexus S is also compatible.

headline: Still Carrying The Ball
summary: Jim Brown has played many roles in his 60 years in the public spotlight: football star, lacrosse legend (some consider him the best lacrosse player ever), actor, social activist and more. He has added plaintiff, in a lawsuit against Electronic Arts for portraying him - not by name or face, but by weight, height, years in the league, skill rating and skin color - on the 1965 Cleveland Browns team in the Madden video-game series. The suit was dismissed in district court but is being considered by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Brown, 75, spoke by phone about the case, the lockout and his wearing yet another hat: pole-vaulter. Q. It seems that most football lawsuits these days deal with the lockout, but what is yours about?

headline: A New Subscription Model
summary: Time Inc. has a memo for Apple: We're not waiting at the altar forever. We have Google. As magazine publishers continue their discussions with Apple to sell subscriptions on the iPad, Time Inc. has begun selling subscription bundles that include apps that run on the Android tablet software from Google.

headline: THE BLOG: G.M. Invests in Battery Firm
summary: A Michigan lithium-ion battery developer, which is working on new technology the company says can give electric cars greater range, plans to announce on Friday that it has received $3.2 million from General Motors Ventures. G.M. said the new batteries could eventually end up in the company's cars. The battery company, Sakti3, is headed by Ann Marie Sastry, chief executive and a professor at the University of Michigan, who is working on solid-state batteries that may offer higher energy density, lower cost and smaller size than conventional lithium-ion batteries.

headline: Aftermarket Earphones Made Especially for HTC Phones
summary: HTC has had certifiable hits with it Android phones such as the Incredible, the EVO and now the Thunderbolt. But these phones miss the mark for many people using aftermarket headphones because some have features that don't work with HTC handsets. Headphone maker NOCS is introducing a new model of its NS200 Aluminum earphones made especially for HTC handsets.

headline: Music Software for the Pros, Retooled for Windows Users
summary: Music-minded Mac users have GarageBand, which is bundled on all new Macs, to create and edit music. Windows computers, by comparison, don't include music-creation software, and that has left some users singing the blues. Unaccompanied. And that is why I was interested in taking a look at new consumer hardware and software bundles from Avid, the company that owns Pro Tools and Sibelius, the music recording and notation software used by composers and professional musicians.

headline: Monopoly, Under the Watchful Eye of a Digital Arbiter
summary: Coming this fall are versions of classic board games like Monopoly that watch your every move and know whose turn is next. In Monopoly Live ($50), you still land on Boardwalk and collect $200 for passing go. But the money flows electronically to your bankcard, and a computer manages such details as dice rolls and rent calculations, which can speed the pace of the game.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ZIELINSKI, EDWARD A.
summary: ZIELINSKI--Edward A.,on June 1st, 2011, he had a long distinguished career in information technology, affiliated over the years with Lucent, AT&T and Pfizers, Inc. Survived by his brothers Richard and Robert. Memorial services to be announced at a later date.

headline: A Public Fight Over Patents
summary: Updated 10:59 a.m. Friday: Added Microsoft's comment to Google's response. Updated 4:30 p.m. Thursday:Added a response from Google. Google and Microsoft are at it again.

headline: It's a Phone, It's a Laptop, It's a Fast and Fancy Atrix
summary: If there has been a muted response to what is arguably the most powerful mobile phone currently made - the Atrix - it may be due to its parentage. The phone comes from Motorola. The once-mighty Motorola dominated the mobile phone market quarter after quarter with products like the reliable and stylish Razr, but was knocked off its pedestal by the iPhone.

headline: Groupon Pulls Its Much-Criticized Super Bowl Ads
summary: Groupon is ending a campaign that made its debut on Super Bowl Sunday, days after making changes in response to considerable criticism of the ads. The decision is a major setback for Groupon, the purveyor of online discount coupons, because the campaign represented its first national mainstream advertising.

headline: Drug Sales for Executions Are Halted
summary: A Danish manufacturer of a drug used in executions announced Friday that it would no longer sell to prisons that perform lethal injections. Ulf Wiinberg, the chief executive of Lundbeck Inc., said the company ''adamantly opposes the distressing misuse of our product in capital punishment.'' The drug, sodium pentobarbital, a barbiturate, has become a substitute drug for many states in light of shortages of a similar drug, sodium thiopental. ''We can't make guarantees'' that prisons will not circumvent the sales controls, he said, but ''we are confident that our new distribution program will play a substantial role in restricting prisons' access'' to the drug. Maya Foa, an investigator with the anti-death-penalty group Reprieve, said the move shows that ''any company manufacturing execution drugs and refusing to take such steps will therefore be directly complicit in executions.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ROBINSON, HENRIETTA TRUESDELL
summary: ROBINSON--Henrietta Truesdell, passed away on June 27, 2011, after a short illness at the age of 95. Born in New York City on September 20, 1915, she was the daughter of Dr. Edward Delavan Truesdell, a surgeon, and the former Henrietta Norton. Mrs. Robinson graduated from Brearley School and Smith College. In 1941 she married Horace Brookes Blackwell Robinson, former partner at the law firm of Dewey Ballantine. She is survived by three children, Edward T. Robinson, Dr. Thomas D. Robinson, and J. Howland Robinson, and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Brick Church, Park Ave. at 91st St., at 3pm on Friday, July 29, 2011. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Brick Church, 62 E. 92nd St., New York, NY 10128, or US English Foundation, Inc., 1747 Pennsylvania Ave, NW, Suite 1050, Washington, DC 20006.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths CHIN, OYMIN
summary: CHIN--Oymin, 57, of Brooklyn, NY passed away on Friday, July 1, 2011. Judge Chin presided in the Civil Courts of New York City. Beloved wife of Edmond David. Loving and devoted mother of Alexander David. Cherished daughter of Big T. and the late Quock Chin. Dear sister of Lemin Chin. Adored aunt of Lianne Chin. The family will receive relatives and friends Tuesday, July 5, 2011, 10 am to 1:30pm at Vander Plaat Colonial Home, Inc., 13-31 Saddle River Road, Fair Lawn, NJ, 201-797-3500. Interment will follow at George Washington Memorial Park in Paramus. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Oymin may be made to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation, 785 Springfield Avenue, Summit, NJ 07901. For additional information, please visit: www.vpfairlawn.com.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KELLER, BARBARA T
summary: KELLER--Barbara T. 85, passed away peacefully on May 6th joining her beloved husband of 60 years, C. Lawrence Keller. Originally from South Orange, NJ, Barbara was a longtime resident of Short Hills, NJ, and Londonderry, VT. Barbara graduated from Miss Beard's School and in 1945 from Bennett Junior College before working at J. Walter Thompson until her marriage in 1949. In 1977 Barbara graduated with honors from Union County Technical School in occupation therapy. She began her career in health care at Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation catalyzing her interest in alternative healing. She studied Therapeutic Touch at the NYU College of Nursing and advocated the contemporary healing modality as a practitioner and teacher for 30 years. Barbara was a dedicated humanitarian who supported numerous causes. Most notably, she served nine years on the Board of Trustees of Cheshire Home in Florham Park, a residence for the disabled. She also was a board member of Canterbury Village in West Orange and an early supporter the Interweave Center for Holistic Living in Summit. An avid sportswoman, Barbara was a member of the Short Hills Club, Baltusrol Golf Club, Ekwanok Country Club in Manchester, VT, Sankaty Head Golf Club in Nantucket, MA, and Tuscarora Club in Margaretville, NY. Barbara is survived by four children; Cord, Jim (Elissa), Linny Andlinger (Rick) and Nick (Marnie) and four grandchildren; Nick Andlinger, Emily, Franny and Everett. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Stephen's Church in Millburn, NJ at 11am on May 26. In lieu of flowers, she requested sending a donation to Cheshire Home, Inc., 9 Ridgedale Ave., Florham Park, NJ, 07932 or Interweave, 31 Woodland Ave., Summit, NJ, 07901. For online condolences, please visit: moriartyfuneralhome.com

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GILL, JOHN L.
summary: GILL--John Lee, of New York died August 10, 2011, at Chester River Manor. He was 88. He was born in Chestertown, Maryland, the son of the late Charles Lee Gill, Jr. and Mable Coppage Gill. Mr. Gill was preceded in death by his wife, T. Smyth Gill, and his brother, William Thomas Hepburn Gill. Survivors include his sister, Jean Gill Smith of Centreville, MD and several nieces and nephews. John was a Veteran of World War II, serving as a Naval Aviator in the Western Pacific, mainly on the USS Santee CVE 29. After the war he returned to Chestertown and completed Washington College and then served as a Special Agent, Federal Bureau of Investigation from 1951 to 1977, assigned to offices in the Midwest, West and New York City. He was an active volunteer with the New York City Fire Department, being honored as an â€œHonorary Deputy Chief, Fire Department, New York and the USS Intrepid CV 19 Aircraft Carrier Museum where he was presented with a Seat of Honor aboard the Intrepid on Memorial Day 2011. Also, John was a member of The Fire Bell Club of New York, Entrepid Museum Volunteers, U.S. Naval Institute, Society of Former Special Agents of the FBI, Inc. and the Escort Carrier Sailors and Airmen Association. A Memorial Service will be held at 2pm, on September 24, 2011 at the Church of the Incarnation, 209 Madison Avenue (Corner of Madison and 35th Sts), New York, NY 10016 (Inquiries at 212-689-6350). In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations be made in memory of John to the New York Firefighters Burn Center Foundation, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx, New York, NY 10475 (718-379-1900).

headline: Unlimited Data As Selling Point
summary: While Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, and Andy Rubin, the vice president of engineering at Google, fire pot shots at one another over their rival cellphone platforms, the wireless carriers are engaging in their own snipefest behind the scenes. Several media outlets, including Engadget, a technology blog, are reporting that Verizon Wireless is preparing to introduce tiered data plans for its smartphone subscribers.

headline: Twitter to Raise $400 Million, Remaining Private for Now

headline: Taking a Walk With Zuckerberg

Although the hiking path is often the same, through a wooded area of Palo Alto that skirts Stanford University, those invited change each time.

headline: A Driving Range Where Playing's the Thing

Scattered between the thumps and thwacks will be soft, beseeching whispers. Someone will, of course, be talking business on the cellphone. Someone else will be asking for advice, or giving it. Someone will be shouting the most tortured lamentations and swearing off golf forever.

headline: DealBook Online

The move could allay fears that JPMorgan could face a big credit risk if it were forced to hold the loan -- the biggest ever by a single bank -- on its books. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

headline: Using Points At Amazon

headline: Time Inc.'s New Chief Shakes Up Magazine Unit, Creating a Sports Group

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths CHIN, OYMIN

Loving and devoted mother of Alexander David. Cherished daughter of Big T. and the late Quock Chin. Dear sister of Lemin Chin. Adored aunt of Lianne Chin. The family will receive relatives and friends Tuesday, July 5, 2011, 10 am to 1:30pm at Vander Plaat Colonial Home, Inc., 13-31 Saddle River Road, Fair Lawn, NJ, 201-797-3500. Interment will follow at George Washington Memorial Park in Paramus. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Oymin may be made to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation, 785 Springfield Avenue, Summit, NJ 07901. For additional information, please visit: www.vpfairlawn.com.

headline: A Better Way To Measure Twitter Influence
summary: Whether you're a Twitter user like Lady Gaga (millions and millions of followers) or, say, me (2,600 and growing!), you're always aware of roughly how many people follow you. It's just how people keep score on the site and compare themselves to friends and colleagues. But it turns out that counting followers is a seriously flawed way to measure a person's impact on Twitter. Even Twitter's co-founder, Evan Williams, made the point to me recently: someone with millions of followers may no longer post messages frequently, while someone followed by mere tens of thousands may be a prolific poster whose messages are amplified by others.

headline: Financier And Banker To Face Off On EMI Sale

headline: Before Rush, One Tablet Stands Out

Apple sold 15 million iPads in nine months, so you can bet that 2011 will be the Year of the iPad Clone.

headline: Three New Tricks for Gmail's Priority Inbox

summary: A few days ago, I described how a stay-at-home mom named Amy Gottesman built a six-figure party-entertainment business largely via the effective use of Google AdWords and other pay-per-click advertising services. These services allow a company to bid on certain keywords and phrases, and if the bid is high enough a short ad from the company will appear alongside the search results of anyone typing those words into a search engine and on some other Web sites. The business then pays the bid price -- it can be anywhere from pennies to more than a thousand dollars depending on the competition for those words -- every time someone clicks on the ad.

headline: A Moment With Larry Fink
summary: Larry Fink, born in 1941, started taking photographs as an adolescent. His work has been exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art, among others, and he was the recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship in 1976. His books include "Social Graces" (1984, reissued 2001), "Boxing" (1997), "Runway" (2000) and "The Vanities: Hollywood Parties 2000-2009," which will be published this year by Schirmer/Mosel. He is a professor of photography at Bard College. This conversation, with Adriana Teresa, the co-founder of FotoVisura and the publisher of Visura Magazine, has been edited and condensed.

headline: Playing a Sad Song for Joy: Mark Seliger
