And he has put together a book, with Rizzoli, that sharpens the senses for the silent and seemingly insignificant. He is well known for his portraits of actors and musicians and his fashion work for magazines, among them Vanity Fair and Italian Vogue. "Listen" displays a natural feeling for things that hover between ordinary and monumental, sad and self-renewing. You can catch his show of photographs from "Listen" at the Steven Kasher Gallery in Chelsea; it closes on Saturday. Here's an excerpt from our recent conversation.

headline: Early Oscar Ratings Suggest Slightly Fewer Viewers Than Last Year

headline: Golden Girl

Wearing a white Chanel minidress that contained -- at least, to a degree -- her famously curvaceous torso while still showing off her long, perpetually tanned legs, the 23-year-old Ms. Lively seemed, at times, to have trouble believing that she was the focal point of the room. After greeting the designer Tory Burch and Vogue's event director, Sylvana Soto-Ward, and hopping up and down in wobbly heels upon seeing John Galantic, the president of Chanel, Ms. Lively eventually made her way to a table. ''I was just having a conversation and I looked down and saw 'Chanel: Dinner in Honor of Blake Lively' '' she said, pointing to her menu. ''It's crazy.''

The DVD isn't dead yet, but it's definitely looking a little peaked, at least in the eyes of the home-video industry. Sales continue to decline (volume is down about 40 percent from this time last year for the Top 20 titles, according to Home Media Magazine), the formerly ubiquitous neighborhood rental shops have all but vanished (Blockbuster, once the dominant franchise, has plunged into bankruptcy), and the major studios have drastically cut back on full-scale releases of library titles.

headline: Luggage Tags

For the Tumi project - which will be limited to 1,000 of each case in the four-piece collection - Matos explains that he "didn't sit there thinking, What would be cool on a Tumi bag?" headline: Fuel Costs And Quake Cut Revenue At Airlines
summary: The first quarter is always weak one for airlines, as travel drops with the start of the new year. But this one was especially difficult, the airlines reported Thursday, as fuel prices spiked and Middle East unrest and the earthquake in Japan cut into demand for international flights. The rise in jet fuel prices -- up 50 percent in the last year -- has been particularly tough, airline executives said. And even though the airlines have repeatedly resorted to fare increases this year, higher fuel costs have largely eroded their revenue gains. Fuel now accounts for about 40 percent of an airline's costs, up from about 30 percent last year.

headline: What ‘Hobbit’ Curse? Jackson’s Movies Get Star-Crossed Release Dates
summary: As if to prove that there are no supernatural forces working against Peter Jackson’s “Hobbit” movies, for which that director has already contended with a labor dispute, the occasional explosion and emergency ulcer surgery, the studios have settled on some interesting release dates for the two-part fantasy epic. New Line Cinema, Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer said in a joint statement reported by The Associated Press that the first “Hobbit” movie would open on Dec. 14, 2012, when some scholars say is the 509th anniversary of the birth of Nostradamus, the French astrologer and soothsayer. (Historical spoilsports say he was born on Dec. 21.) And the concluding “Hobbit” film will be released on Dec. 13, 2013, a date that not only has two 13s but is also, wouldn’t you know it, Friday the 13th.

headline: Calvin Klein Resort: Silver Linings
summary: Francisco Costa’s modest resort collection for Calvin Klein flowed easily from his fall line, with a fluid fit, an abundance of long-sleeved looks, and not too many surprises until the very end of the show. One difference is length; on Wednesday, in the Calvin Klein showroom, Mr. Costa’s hemlines were below the knee. Most styles, including a dark navy coat dress in crepe de chine and a collarless jacket in wool shown with a matching georgette skirt, came with a thin belt. For women looking for a break from the scuba and urban-surfer looks on the runways, Mr. Costa is your answer. He didn’t show any color, which is perhaps too bad. His evening looks were exceptional — a distraction of sexy halter and tank dresses in black or white silk suspended on sterling silver bands.

Even as recently as June 2010, I thought we’d hit sales of “$16 million in 2010.” We finished the year at $13.5 million.

headline: It’s About Time | A Nouveau Tourneau
summary: Blocks away from its clock swamped, tourist-enticing flagship “Time Machine” store on 57th Street, Tourneau has just opened a new concept store. Same time zone, different world. Created by Eight Inc., the designers behind the state-of-the-art Apple stores, this soaring modernist space eschews the traditional “behind-the-counter” retail approach in favor of a more user-friendly shopping experience. Eight large watch tables allow for accessible, easy viewing from all sides, while digital screens embedded in walls feature informative, up-to-the-minute videos. The store also features its own Rolex boutique — New York City’s first — which occupies almost a third of the space. To celebrate the new Madison Avenue location, Tourneau has launched a new line of timepieces, the TNY series, with the clean lines and strong look of the city that inspired it. The Rush Hour watch, made from the high performance alloy DLC, features numerals and hands in vivid yellow. Hey taxi!

headline: Now Selling | Textfield Titles at Creatures of Comfort

Through Aug. 25, works by the artists Phil Chang, Arthur Ou, Eduardo Sarabia and Anna Sew Hoy — all Textfield Inc. favorites — play a supporting role to the printing house founder Jonathan Maghen’s curiously obscure and graphic selection of paperbacks and monographs. No book costs more than $100 (not even the artist Jennifer Doyle’s lovingly compiled “Municipal du Futbol,” about amateur soccer in Los Angeles, which includes two clothbound books, a jersey, nine artist lithographs and a poster). Pick up “The Portable John Latham” or the hilarious “Hippie Photos and Surfer Man” by the photographer Doniella Davy while you shop for Maison Martin Margiela clothes and Robert Clergerie shoes (fall’s tassel-top loafers and embossed leather wedges just arrived, p.s.).

headline: Oh Baby Answers Its Chicken-and-Egg Question

On the other hand, she couldn’t ramp up production without the promise of some much-needed business. Oh Baby’s 2010 monthly sales were about $2,000. His contribution has nothing, and I mean nothing* to do with the fact that TIME Magazine contributor Joel Stein, who appeared here in June (Across Lite, Solution, blog), accused him of being smug or perhaps even too smart for his own good. This is a blog about crossword puzzles, after all, and it would certainly not be appropriate to use this forum to stoke the fires of competitiveness or to provoke two renowned journalists into a public face-off, no matter how much fun I could have doing it.

headline: Over the Cliff
summary: I fell into a Supreme Court time warp the other day. Preparing to teach a seminar this fall on the court under Chief Justice Warren E. Burger - the court of the 1970s to mid-'80s - I picked up for the first time in many years a decision from 1978, First National Bank of Boston v. Bellotti. The case is not well-known today, although it should be. It was the decision that really opened the door to corporate money in politics, leading 32 years later to a very well-known case: Citizens United.

headline: Irene Adds To Bad Year For Insurers
